content: What kind of metaphysics do you find helpful in explaining a Lindy Hop dance? I found people using the words from classical physics such as speed, momentum, force, potential energy, geometry such as circumference, curvature, line, but they never seem right to me. Is there anything from relationalism physics that people can borrow to explain dancing (Lindy Hop in particular) better?
A video example: https://youtu.be/26-1t15R_MU

Could you give some examples as to why classical mechanics does not seem to fit from your perspective? I've always found classical physics to be a competely adequate background for dancing as well as other sports disciplines.
Do you find classical mechanics to be insufficient for other physical activities as well? If not, what makes the difference between dancing and other sports, or between Lindy Hop and other dances?

Disclaimer: My experience with ballroom dancing is rather limited, and includes almost no Lindy Hop.
I found classical physics rather mechanical and was expecting relationalism physics gives a better picture. If I were to be okay with dancing robotically I would be satisfied with the classical.
If I wanted to think about the physics of dancing I would start by reading a bunch of papers about it.

Two cents as an avid Lindy Hopper: when leading, your decision which move to lead often exists in a superposition, then when the follow reacts you 'collapse' to a decision and actually perform the move. So in that sense Lindy hop is quantum ;)
I'm being kind of silly. When I dance I don't think of metaphysics, I just think 'weee, feet go brrrr'

John van de Wetering said:

Two cents as an avid Lindy Hopper: when leading, your decision which move to lead often exists in a superposition, then when the follow reacts you 'collapse' to a decision and actually perform the move. So in that sense Lindy hop is quantum :wink:

Very true for tango as well

Actually it's even more complicated. One common misconception is that leader leads by imposing moves and follower just reacts accordingly. In truth, leader proposes: You make a move and there is an entire spectrum of things that are 'good reactions' for the follower to make. Usually there is one very obvious way to react to some proposition but a skilled follower can surprise you almost at every step. This is really funny because you can witness 'nonverbal arguments' between leader and follower, where leader wants to do something and follower basically says 'no way I am going to do that!", but from the point of view of an untrained person everything looks pretty normal :grinning:
